constraints: Completeness ("narrow"): The response restricts the discussion to a very small slice of the topic, avoiding broad context.

Scope ("motifs"): The response focuses on recurring structural or thematic forms that appear in multiple places, identifying repeated configurations or isomorphic patterns without analyzing their internal topology in detail or their boundary-spanning distribution.

Form ("test"): The response presents test cases in a structured format with clear setup, execution, and assertion sections, organized by scenario type (happy path, edge cases, errors, boundaries) and including descriptive test names.
Channel ("code"): The response consists only of code or markup as the complete output, with no surrounding natural-language explanation or narrative.
Directional ("dip bog"): The response modifies the task to start with concrete examples and grounded details, examines their structure and reflects on patterns, then identify actions and extensions.
